bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, February 5, 1923

div1.p: Griffitts writes about water impoundment and mosquito control in Alabama. He regrets that he is not going to North Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, February 5, 1923
div1.opener:
I. W
Griffitts
BUREAUS
VITAL STATISTICS
HYGIENIC LABORATORY
ENGINEERING
COUNTY ORGANIZATION
VENEREAL DISEASE CONTROL
CHILD HYGIENE AND PUBLIC
HEALTH NURSING
EPIDEMIOLOGY
INSPECTION
PUBLICITY, EDUCATION
AND PRINTING
TUBERCULOSIS CONTROL
{STATE OF ALABAMA
ALABAMA STATE BOARD OF HEALTH}
519 DEXTER AVENUE
MONTGOMERY
Feb. 5, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I changed headquarters from Mobile to Montgom-
ery February 1, and after straightening up somewhat
am leaving for Dothon this evening to look into
a pond condition - impounded just two years ago-
in 1921 (first season) Out of a population of 168
questioned 59% gave histories of mal; in 1922 out of
203, 79%, with one death.

Le Prince, Hazleburst, Mr. Carter and others
found scant breeding along shore- no boat there
to examine body- no quad breeding to speak of
outside pond. A. q. in houses, goodly numbers, for
a distance of a mile from the pond. I can determine
little now, for the normal physical conditions for
winter even have been disturbed by very heavy
rains in past 24 hours. The shore line was ex-
amined at different times, giving negative
results as compared with imagos. It would
seen that (a) some condition allowed of intermittent
heavy breeding along shore (and perhaps body) or
(b) breeding away from shore. I may decide
to take this as one of the small ponds (200 acres)
for close seasonal study.

I am disappointed in not getting to North
Carolina. Le P. told me he agreed with you
that N. C. would have been best for my
work. If your advice, and LeP's, is not
wise enough to guide me - I - just regret it,
I guess. I could never see that its' beneficial
to try to work hardships on anyone to put the me
in a mental attitude for (?) work.

I had hoped to have the pleasure and profit
of your visits to me at Charlotte. I understand
Mr. Goye is to go to North Carolina.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, T. H. D. Griffitts-
P.S.
The Mobile work was good - if one is
capable of judging his own work. I found, however,
that drainage of the large “3 mile Creek” swamp is
necessary. I succeeded in doing about one-fourth
of it. The best “dehydrating” job I have ever
seen. One ditch unwatered a parallel strip
500' wide and this cut short by the hard
railroad fill, for on the opposite side water
stands as before; on the ditch side not a drop
for a mile.
